FAQ

Expand All
  • What are the differences between the Basic, General Purpose, and Memory Optimized tiers?

    Basic tier is designed for workloads that require light compute and I/O performance. Examples include servers for development or testing or infrequently used small-scale applications. General Purpose tier is suitable for most business workloads that require balanced compute, memory and scalable I/O throughput. Examples include servers for hosting web and mobile apps, as well as other enterprise applications. Memory Optimized tier is for high performance database workloads that require in-memory performance for faster transaction processing and higher concurrency. Examples include servers for processing real-time data and high-performance transactional or analytical applications. For more details, please see documentation.

  • How is the bill calculated?

    For all tiers, the service is billed on a predictable, hourly rate based on the pricing tier, provisioned compute in vCore, as well as storage (GB/month) provisioned for servers and backups. vCore hours, storage (GB/month) of servers and storage (GB/month) of backups are itemized separately on the bill.

    In addition, starting September 1, 2018, you will also be billed for the number of I/Os used per month.

  • What if a single MySQL server is active for less than an hour or uses a higher pricing tier for less than an hour, how would it be billed?

    You are billed for each hour or less than an hour that a MySQL exists, regardless of whether the server is active for the full hour. If the database is scaled, you will be billed based on the highest pricing tier, provisioned vCore and storage during the hour.

    For example:

    • If you create a MySQL server and delete it after 5 minutes, you will be charged for one full hour for the provisioned compute and storage.
    • If you create a MySQL server in the General Purpose tier with 8 vCores, and immediately upgrade it to 16 vCores in the General Purpose tier, you will be charged based on 16 vCores for the first hour.
  • Do I need to bear any network data transfer costs?

    Starting from July 1, 2018, network data egress will be charged based on standard rates. For details, please see here.

  • How are backup costs calculated?

    Backup storage is the storage associated with the automatic backups of the server. Increasing your backup retention period increases the backup storage that is consumed by your MySQL server. There is no extra cost for backup storage for up to 100% of your total provisioned server storage. Additional consumption of backup storage will be charged in GB/month. For example, if the database storage is 100GB, you will receive 100GB of backup storage at no extra cost. However, if your backup is 110GB, you will be billed for the 10GB.

Support & SLA

If you have any questions or need help, please visit Azure Support and select self-help service or any other method to contact us for support.

MySQL Database on Azure provides a Service Level Agreement for 99.9% operating time to ensure high availability and business continuity for users. To learn more about the details of our Service Level Agreement, please visit the Service Level Agreements page.
